Fig 19 Review Two-dimensional polymer-based nanosheets for electrochemical energy storage and conversion Shuai Bi a # Chenbao Lu a # Wenbei Zhang a Feng Qiu b ⁎ Fan Zhang a ⁎ a School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, State Key Laboratory of Metal Matrix Composites, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai 200240, China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering State Key Laboratory of Metal Matrix Composites Shanghai Jiao Tong University Shanghai 200240 China b School of Chemical and Environmental Engineering, Shanghai Institute of Technology, Shanghai 201418, China School of Chemical and Environmental Engineering Shanghai Institute of Technology Shanghai 201418 China ⁎ Corresponding authors. # These two authors contributed equally to this work. Over the past decades, two-dimensional (2D) nanomaterials possessing planar layered architecture and unique electronic structures have been being quickly developed, due to their wide potential application in the fields of chemistry, physics, and materials science. As a new family of 2D nanomaterials, 2D polymer-based nanosheets, featuring excellent characters, such as tunable framework structures, light weight, flexibility, high specific surface, and good semiconducting properties, have been emerging as one kind of promising functional materials for optoelectronics, gas separation, catalysis and sensing, etc. In this review, the recent progress in synthetic approach and characterization of 2D polymer-based nanosheets were summarized, and their current advances in electrochemical energy storage and conversion including second batteries, supercapacitors, oxygen reduction and hydrogen evolution were discussed systematically. Graphical abstract The 2D polymer-based nanosheets featuring substantially tunable porous structures and morphologies, as well as versatile promising properties, highly desirable for secondary batteries, supercapacitors, oxygen reduction, and hydrogen evolution. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Two-dimensional polymer Nanosheet Nanoscale morphology Electrochemical performance Energy storage and conversion 1 Introduction With the overconsumption of natural resources (like oil and coal), energy shortages, as well as air pollution and global warming are emerging and threatening the development of modern society [1,2]. Thus, the demand for clean and renewable energy has attracted great attention in both academic and industrial fields in the past decades. Owing to the intrinsic existence of redox activity in chemical elements, electrochemical performance is considered as one of the most efficient methods for energy storage and conversion [3–5]. Together with the development of nanotechnology, various electronic devices, such as rechargeable batteries, supercapacitors and sensors, would become prospective products to improve the quality of life greatly [6–10]. Thus, design and construction of active electrode materials with rational microstructure and macrostructure to gain promising electrochemical behaviors are mandatory and urgent (Fig. 1 ). To date, many materials have been investigated in search for the best performance for electrochemical energy storage. For example, noble metal materials (e.g. Pt, Au) typically are the most efficient electrocatalysts. Unfortunately, the scarcity and high cost of these catalysts severely restricted their practical applications [11,12]. Recently, two-dimensional (2D) nanomaterials, such as graphene [13,14], hexagonal boron-carbon-nitrogen [15–18], black phosphorus [19–22], metal oxide [23]/chloride [24]/sulfide [25,26]/selenide [27,28] and perovskite sheets [29], MXene [30] possess planar layered architecture, in which the lateral dimension is several orders of magnitude larger than that of thickness. 2D nanomaterials exhibit the rich chemical modification, anisotropic characters, excellent electrical properties as well as high specific surface areas, in comparison to that of zero-dimensional (0D), one dimensional (1D) nanomaterials [31]. Combined with their abundance sources, these 2D materials are reasonably suitable as the alternative key active components for applications in electrochemical devices [5,32]. Among the various 2D nanomaterials, graphene, a flat monolayer of carbon atoms arranged in a two-dimensional (2D) honeycomb lattice, exhibits intriguing physical and chemical properties, including high charge mobility, superior thermal conductivity, large specific surface area, good chemical stability [33]. Moreover, the layer-by-layer self-assembly of graphene and other 2D nanomaterials with large overlapping areas into the graphene nanocomposites would bring them high mechanical properties as well as some superior electrochemical properties, originating from electrochemical activities in the 2D lattice plane [34,35]. These intriguing properties endow graphene-based nanosheets with great potential application in energy storage and conversion [36,37]. Unfortunately, the full-carbon of graphene with sp2 -hybridization gives the zero bandgap, limiting its applications, such as, low electrochemical capacity [31]. To overcome this obstacle, incorporating heteroatoms (e.g. B, N, S, P, halogens) into the carbon backbone of graphene represents an efficient strategy to finely tune the electrochemical performance for energy storage and conversion [38–45]. However, the quantitative preparation of these functionalized graphene is still the major challenge, which would limit the need for device fabrication in large scale. In this regard, searching for new 2D nanomaterials with high conductivity, controllable hierarchical porous structure, and good electrochemical activity is highly desirable in electrochemical energy storage research. Alternatively, 2D polymer-based nanosheets, including 2D polymers [46–52], covalent organic frameworks (COFs) [53–59], 2D supramolecular organic nanostructures [60–65], etc, are the one of most fascinating fields, which open a novel avenue to the construction of 2D functionalized nanomaterials for various applications [66,67]. These nanosheets not only have similar planar, light-weight and flexible characteristics to graphene, but also hold the great advantages in structural control [68]. With the help of efficient chemical synthesis, heteroatoms can be incorporated into the frameworks of 2D polymeric nanosheets through the polymerization of heteroaromatic-based building blocks, like aniline [69,70], pyrrole [71,72], tricyanobenzene [73], dopamine [74], phthalocyanine [54], etc. Moreover, the thickness of nanosheets could be facile to be controlled by the combination of the molecular weight of polymers and precision macromolecular self-assembly approach [75]. In the past years, the remarkable achievements in synthesis, characterization, theoretical calculation and application of 2D polymer-based nanosheets have been witnessed. Even previous reviews have been concerned in the construction, properties and application of some branches of 2D polymeric nanomaterials, like COFs [53,76–78]. However, a systematic review on the synthesis of 2D polymer-based nanosheets for the application in electrochemical energy storage has not yet been documented as far as we know. Typically, high electrochemically-active nanomaterials exhibit some attractive features as following: (i) interconnected porous structures with large specific surface areas; (ii) good conductivity; (iii) intrinsic electrochemical active sites [79,80]. To meet the critical needs above, 2D polymer-based nanosheets with well-defined hierarchical architectures comprising microporous and mesoporous structure have been extensively developed on the basis of versatile polymerization methods and highly designable functional building blocks. In this feature article, we particularly highlight the synthesis methodologies of 2D polymer-based nanosheets. Their applications in electrochemical energy storage and conversion including second batteries, supercapacitors, oxygen reduction, and hydrogen evolution were also summarized. 2 Design and synthesis of 2D polymer-based nanosheets Polymer-based nanosheets are materials of quasi-two-dimensional (2D) nanostructure composed of the covalent-linked repetitive monomers in the plane with single or few layers in the perpendicular direction [67,81]. Thus, synthesis of 2D polymer-based nanosheets involves the periodic covalent bonding of monomers with multifunctional groups in two or more orthogonal directions. However, using the traditional polymerization approach, bulk hyper-crosslinked polymers [82–84] or dendritic polymers [85–87], rather than 2D polymer-based nanosheets, are often obtained due to the twisted conformation of polymer chains with respect to the free rotation of chemical bonds. With the rapid development in the preparation and applications of 2D polymer-based nanosheets, a remarkable progress has been made to establish the applicable pathways to 2D polymer-based nanosheets for device fabrications. To date, a general synthesis strategy is the confined polymerization of monomers into 2D geometry without layer coupling through the isolation of intermolecular weak interaction or interfacial interaction [88]. Great effort to review of 2D polymers has been contributed by Schlüter and co-workers and Zhang and co-workers [67,81]. Here, the very recent advancement in the synthetic approaches to 2D polymer-based nanosheets, involving random polymerization, interfacial polymerization and templated polymerization, is presented, demanding for their potential application in energy field. 2.1 Random polymerization In a solution, covalent synthesis of 2D nanosheets with periodic structures from repetitive monomers should meet the requirements for building blocks with rigid conformation and appropriate reactive groups [88]. Typically, 2D covalent organic frameworks (COFs), a kind of covalent crystalline porous polymer, could be constructed by the polymerization of planar building blocks through reversible dynamic covalent reactions in an appropriate solvent [89]. In such 2D COFs, the backbones of polymers were covalently grown into single-layer nanosheets, which could stack into periodical aligned columns by means of layer-by-layer molecular self-assembly. To access their electrochemical properties, post synthesis has been considered as the one of the most facile strategies for the functionalization of COFs [90,91]. Jiang and co-workers synthesized imine-linked COFs consisting of nickel porphyrin and bis(2-propynyloxy) benzene under conventional solvothermal conditions (Fig. 2 ). Then, the redox active 2,2,6,6-tetramethyl-1-piperidinyloxy could be grafted quantitatively onto COF to form electrochemically active TEMPO-COF via click reaction at a smooth condition, owing to the existence of ethynyl units on the channel wall [92]. Recently, incorporation of redox building blocks into the aromatic frameworks of 2D COFs has proven to be one of most efficient approach. Dichtel and coworkers reported a redox-active 2D COF (DAAQ-TFP) with β-ketoenamine-linkage, obtained by polycondensation of 2,6-diaminoanthraquinone (DAAQ) and 1,3,5-triformylphloroglucinol (TFP) under solvothermal conditions [93] (Fig. 3 a). Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of DAAQ-TFP exhibited an intense diffraction peak at 3.5°, 5.9°, 7.0°, and a broad peak at 27°, corresponding to the typical of 2D layered hexagonal networks with 100, 110, 210, and 001 reflections, respectively. The resulting sample exhibited Type IV N2 adsorption isotherms with a Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area (S BET) of 1124 ± 422 m2 g−1 and pore size distribution at 20 Å, which is reasonably close to the theoretical calculation. Subsequently, Tang and co-workers reported a redox-active 2D COF with pyridine moieties by condensing diaminopyridine (DAP) with TFP in dioxane at 120 °C for 2 days [94], which showed the nearly eclipsed stacked layered structures comprised of continuous nanoscale ordered pores and significant π-orbital overlapping within the monomers of adjacent layers, confirming by experimental and simulated PXRD results (Fig. 3b). Owing to the superior electrochemical reversibility in hydroquinone (H2Q)/benzoquinone (Q), Banerjee and co-workers focused on the synthesis of a H2Q based COF (TpPa-(OH)2) by the Schiff base condensation between TFP and 2,5-dihydroxy-1,4-phenyldiamine [Pa-(OH)2] via the solvothermal method (Fig. 3c) [95]. This COF crystallized in a 2D serrated hexagonal network structure with a S BET surface area of 369 m2 g−1 and pore sizes in the range of ∼10–18 Å. However, these 2D COFs revealed the irregular bulky morphologies with flake cluster, may be attributed to the lack of sufficient long-range ordering in their 2D layer structures. To achieve the sheet-like 2D COFs, Wang and coworkers proposed a ball milling strategy to prepare exfoliated COF with few layers from three kinds of redox-active COF, including DAAQ-TFP, DABQ-TFP and TEMPO-COF [96]. As an example of DAAQ-TFP, the exfoliated samples possess ultrathin, transparent and slightly wrinkled layer structures with thicknesses of 3–5 nm, suggesting 10−15 atomic layers. Compared with the less electron-communicated linkages (imine, boronate ester, hydrazine, etc.), exploiting of a 2D COF linked with sp 2-hybridized carbon bonds would be more attractive, due to the extended π-conjugation on the delocalization backbone of COF [97], and thus giving rise of some exceptional electronic and magnetic properties. In 2016, Zhang and coworkers reported the first example of crystalline 2D conjugated COF (2DPPV) with a fully sp2 -bonded carbon skeleton using a Knoevenagel polycondensation reaction of 1,4-phenylene diacetonitrile and three armed aromatic aldehyde (Fig. 4 a) [98]. Experimental and simulated PXRD results revealed that the exact architecture of 2DPPV was proposed to adopt the serrated stacking mode with neighboring layers slipped by 1/4 of the unit cell distance on average with the distance of 0.35 nm, demonstrating the formation of 2D COF sheets with an “A–B–A–B” type alternating arrangement (Fig. 4b and c). The morphology of 2DPPV possessed crystalline flake, yellow semitransparent features with sizes ranging from several to a hundred microns (Fig. 4d). The thickness of 2DPPV measured by AFM was ranged from 50 to 300 nm. Both ball milling exfoliation and solution exfoliation protocols would generate multilayer sheets with an average layer distance of 0.35 nm, which was the typical characteristic of reported 2D COFs. Very recently, using the similar method, Jiang and coworkers reported 2D COF with all sp2 carbon bond by condensation reactions of tetrakis(4-formylphenyl)pyrene and 1,4-phenylenediacetonitrile [99]. This COF showed the extended 2D tetragon lattice with sp2 carbon backbones along the x and y directions and “A-A” type stacking mode with the distance of 3.58 Å. Extensive effort on exploring solution synthesis of conjugated microporous polymers (CMP) with 2D nanosheet structures and controlled redox properties has been conducted all the time [100]. Dai and co-workers synthesized a class of 2D CMPs with precisely controlled locations of N heteroatoms by the nickel-catalyzed Yamamoto homopolymerization of non-noble metals (Fe, Co, Mn) complexed porphyrin monomers in DMF (Fig. 5 a and b) [101]. The resulting CPPs showed the layer texture with high porosities, and the sizes reach to several microns. PXRD results indicated that all of 2D CPPs revealed no long-range crystallographic order, due to the distortion of phenyl rings in the polycondensation process. Using a similar synthesis strategy, clear-cut 2D layer textures could also be obtained by Yamamoto homopolymerization of 2,4,6-tris(4‑bromo‑phenyl)-[1,3,5] triazine, 2,4,6-tris(5-bromothiophen-2-yl)-1,3,5-triazine, and (4′‑bromo‑biphenyl-4-yl)-porphyrine, respectively [102,103]. Similarly, Zhang and co-workers reported the synthesis of sulfur-enriched conjugated polymer nanosheet (2DP-S) consisting of quinoidal polythiophene and poly(p-phenylenevinylene) along horizontal and vertical directions, respectively, through a conventional solution polymerization of 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylic anhydride with the catalyst of phosphorus pentasulfide (Fig. 5c–e) [104]. This as-prepared 2DP-S showed many free-standing nanosheets, in which sizes are ranged from hundred nanometers to several micrometers, and the thickness was uniform at 7.0 ± 1.0 nm. On the basis of chemical structure analysis, these results suggested that the monomers were polymerized into thin polymeric layers in the 2D manner, which stacked together by the strong π–π stacking interaction between the layers. 2.2 Interfacial polymerization The interface of plane substance is the perfect place for constructing of 2D polymer-based nanosheets [105]. Dichetel and co-workers developed a synthesis strategy to the growth of COF films on the surface of copper-supported single-layer graphenes (SLG) by solvothermal condensation [106]. Using this approach, they prepared the crystalline, oriented thin films of a redox active 2D DAAQ-TFP COF on Au working electrodes through the slow addition of TFP DMF solution into a DMF solution of DAAQ at 90 °C [107]. The surface of the obtained COF film was flat, and the thickness of the COF film could be controlled by adjusting the initial DAAQ concentration from 2.2 mM to 22 mM. Similarly, Li and coworkers constructed a high conductive 2D conjugated organic polymers (COP) film of tetrakis(4-thiophenephenyl)porphyrin (TThPP) on the surface of copper foil by in situ chemical oxidative polymerization [108]. The as-prepared TThPP film was completely covered on the copper foil, which was composed of many flat nanosheets with the thickness of 1.2 μm. The ultrathin nanosheets with a thickness of 3.8 nm could also be achieved by exfoliating TThPP films. Deposition of COFs on the surface of solid substance in organic solvent often suffers from the formation of non-uniformed 2D nanosheets. To overcome such drawbacks, recently, Loh and co-workers reported a synthesis route to crystalline 2D conjugated aromatic polymer (2D-CAP) by the Ullmann coupling polymerization of 2,7,13,18-tetrabromodibenzo[a,c]dibenzo[5,6:7,8]quinoxalino-[2,3-i]phenazine (2-TBQP) molecular crystal on the surface of Au(110) under ultra-high vacuum conditions (Fig. 6 ) [109]. Experimental and simulated results demonstrated that the synthesized 2D-CAP showed a highly uniform pore size of ∼0.6 nm, resulting from the aligned 1D open channels created by the stacking of polymeric sheets with the distinct lamellar structure. 2D-CAP could be exfoliated into ultrathin 2D triangular sheets with neat edges, the size consisting in length of ∼15 μm, and the n thickness of ∼1 nm was similar to that of single-layer graphene. The air–liquid interface method in principle offers the preparing of 2D polymer-based nanosheet with unlimited lateral size. Feng and co-workers [110] illustrated the synthesis of wafer-sized 2D COF by Schiff-based polycondensation of 5,10,15,20-tetrakis(4-aminophenyl)-21H,23H-porphine derivatives and 2,5-dihydroxyterephthalaldehyde at an air–water interface of chloroform solution with a surface pressure of 10 mNm−1 by using Langmuir–Blodgett (LB) technique (Fig. 7 ). This 2D COF showed the continuous film with an area to 4 inch and thickness of ∼0.7 nm, suggesting the single-layer feature of the synthesized 2D COF. This freestanding film with a Young's modulus of ∼267 ± 30 GPa could be readily transferred to any substrates without of cracks and folds. At the water–chloroform interface, multilayer 2D COF was prepared by Schiff-base condensation reaction between 5,10,15,20-tetrakis (4-aminophenyl)-21H,23H-porphyrin-Co(II) and 2,5-dihydroxyterephthalaldehyde for 10 days. At the edge of the film, laminar structures with the layer distance of about 0.4 nm were identified, suggesting that multilayer structure of the synthesized 2D COF in a stacked aromatic mode, which had been observed within other 2D layered materials, e.g. few-layer graphene and exfoliated 2D COFs. Conducting polymers, such as polyaniline (PANI), polypyrrole (PPy), are considered to be one of the important candidates for next-generation semiconducting materials [111–114]. However, the preparation of conducting polymer with 2D nanosheets is still difficult to obtain through the conventional oxidative polymerization condition. To achieve the conducting polymer film, in situ liquid–liquid interfacial polymerization has been unitized effectively. Guo and co-workers were unsuccessful to obtain the 2D PANI nanosheet by the oxidative polymerization at the interface between water and chloroform using ammonium persulfate (APS) as the oxidant, even with the existence of graphene oxide (GO) [115]. The reason might be attributed to the inappropriate reaction system of water and chloroform, as well as the fast polymerization from strong oxidant of APS, which underwent the deposition of PANI onto the bottom of vial rather than stabilization on the liquid–liquid interface during the polymerization process. Replacing chloroform with hydrophilic ionic liquid (IL) of 1-ethyl-3-methyl imidazolium tetrafluoroborate ([EMIM]BF4), 2D poly(2,5-dimethoxyaniline) (PDMA) nanosheets could be constructed by interfacial polymerization approach with a mild oxidant of H2O2 [116]. This as-prepared PDMA nanosheets demonstrated a large scale of rippled silk morphology with the thickness ranging from 20 nm to 50 nm. Alternatively, in water and cyclohexane system, polymerization of PPy was conducted by freezing interfacial polymerization method at −20 °C for 4 days, in which pyrrole and oxidant were diffused gradually onto the interface to form 2D conductive PPy film [117]. Such PPy films showed vivid metallic luster, with only some wrinkles in a large scale and the thickness of about 100 nm. To improve the efficiency of liquid–liquid interfacial polymerization, GO has been reported utilized as the template for construction of 2D polymer-based nanosheets. Zhang and co-workers demonstrated an interfacial oxidative polymerization for the fast preparation of a sandwiched graphene-coupled polyaniline nanosheets (GO@PANI) in large quantity (Fig. 8 ) [70]. TEM results showed that GO@PANI revealed an ideal 2D sheet-like morphology with uniformly distributed conical PANI arrays, suggesting the favorable orientation of the PANI growth caused by the static reaction conditions. The thicknesses of the GO@PANI as well as shape of PANI nano-array could be engineered rationally by the weight feed ratio of GO to monomer of aniline. Moreover, various transition metal cations and acid anions also could be anchored on the as-prepared GO@PANI nanosheets. Feng and coworkers reported an electrochemical polymerization of GO@PANI nanosheets at the water/chloroform interface in an ice bath with a galvanostatic current density of 0.5 mA cm−2 for 30 min [118]. For such nanosheets, PANI nanorods with the diameter of ∼30 nm and the length of ∼200 nm were deposited on the surface of GO sheets to form a hierarchical nanostructure, which could be controlled effectively by the diffusion rate of aniline and current density. 2.3 Templated polymerization Due to the harsh experimental conditions for the preparation of 2D polymer-based nanosheet, the deposition of polymers on the 2D nanomaterials as templates, e.g. graphene, to form 2D nanosheets might be much more feasible [106], which paves a new avenue to 2D polymer-based nanosheet with complex structures. Recently, the functionalization of 2D materials, e.g. GO [69,119–121], reduced GO (rGO) [122–126] and molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) [127], with various organic or inorganic components enable creating some additional physical properties, and broaden the potential applications in energy storage and conversion. Zhang and co-workers. developed a graphene-directed synthetic approach to 2D sandwich-like conjugated porous polymers by Sonogashira–Hagihara coupling polymerization of thiophene-, thiazole-, and pyridine-based monomers with 1,3,5-triethynylbenzene monomer on the surface of the bromo‑functionalized rGO (Fig. 9 ) [122]. These freestanding polymer nanosheets showed wrinkled and flexible features with hierarchical porous nanostructures confirmed by TEM measurement. AFM results revealed that the porous polymer sheets possessed the lateral sizes in the range of 200 × 200 nm2 to 1 × 1 μm2 with a uniform thickness of 40 ± 3 nm. The surface areas of these nanosheets varied from 458 to 888 m2 g−1. Using the same polymerization method, halogenated BODIPY as monomer [125] and 4-iodophenyl functionalized MoS2 [127] as a template also could be used to construct 2D conjugated porous polymers nanosheets. Starting from some cheap commercialized reactants, it is possible to achieve 2D polymer-based nanosheets in large scale. In one example, aminated GO (AGO) was readily prepared by the reaction of carboxylic acid groups or epoxide groups of GO with 1,3-diaminopropane. Afterward, the Schiff-base-type 2D porous polymer nanosheets could be synthesized by the general polycondensation of the as-made aminated GO combined with melamine and various aromatic dialdehydes, such as, 1,3-phthalaldehyde, 1,4-phthalaldehyde, 2,5-thiophenedialdehyde, and 4,4′-biphenyldialdehyde [120]. The resultant porous polymer nanosheets possess ultra-high nitrogen contents, free-standing sheet morphologies with the planar sizes in the range of 500 nm to several micrometers, as well as large specific surface areas up to ∼762 m2 g−1. The thicknesses of these nanosheets can be controlled in a broad range of 17−290 nm by changing the weight ratio of AGOs/monomer. Meantime, Using AGO as the template, general oxidation polymerization of aniline, 3-aminophenylboronic acid, and the cross-linker m-phenylenediamine could generate 2D GO-coupling PANI nanosheets functionalized with boronic acid (GO-CBP) [119]. GO-CBP maintained the 2D morphology ranging in the sheet size from 200 nm to several micrometers. The cross-linked PANI afforded the hierarchical micro/mesoporous nanostructure with a specific surface area of 39 m2 g−1. The “grafting-from” strategy beginning from multifunctional 2D materials acted as the macroinitiator provides the controllable synthesis of 2D sandwich-like polymer-based nanosheets [128]. Zhuang and co-workers prepared 2D polyacrylonitrile (PAN) grafted rGO (PAN-g-RGO) in anhydrous THF via anionic polymerization method (Fig. 10 a–c) [123]. AFM results demonstrated that PAN-g-RGO showed the wrinkled and folded surface with an average thickness of ∼7.0 ± 0.5 nm, and the granular-like PAN was covered in the graphene surface uniformly. This method offered an efficient method for the preparation of 2D polymer-based nanosheets with high nitrogen contents. In another example, reversible addition-fragmentation chain transfer (RAFT) emulsion polymerization was conducted to prepare 2D porous polymers (GO-PVD) on a large scale using trithiocarbonate-functionalized GO as a macroinitiator and the mixture of vinylbenzyl chloride and divinylbenzene as monomers (Fig. 10d–f) [121]. The resulting graphene-based hypercrosslinked microporous polymer (GHCP) was produced finally by the FeCl3-promoted Friedel–Crafts reaction. GHCP showed the free-standing sheets with the sizes ranging from 500 nm to several micrometers. Moreover, these samples gave rise to type I nitrogen gas sorption isotherms with H3 hysteresis loops, indicating the existence of micro- and mesopores. The high specific surface areas calculated from BET theory of GHCP reached to 1224 m2 g−1. The non-covalent interactions represents the another popular protocol to the modification of 2D materials with conjugated polymers. Feng and co-workers developed a versatile route to close-packing the surface of 2D materials by hydrophilic-hydrophobic interaction between micelles of block copolymers and 2D materials (Fig. 11 ). Such 2D materials then acted as templates for bottom-up patterning of conductive polymers like polypyrrole and polyaniline on their various free-standing surfaces [75]. As an example of GO-based mesoporous PPy nanosheets synthesized from PS102-b-PEO114, sandwich-like nanosheets possessed flat layered structure with ordered pore array with a pore size of ∼13 nm. The thickness of nanosheets was ∼45 nm, which was almost equal to twice the diameter of PS102-b-PEO114, further confirming the confined growth mechanism of PPy on both sides of the GO surface. The pore features on surfaces of GO could be controlled readily by adjusting the size of amphiphilic polymeric micelles. This strategy allows to functionalize various 2D materials, including MoS2 nanosheet, titania nanosheets, organic nanosheets from 1-pyrenesulfonic acid sodium salt, perfluorocarboxylic acids [129] and octadecylamine [130], with mesoporous conductive PPy. 3 Electrochemical application of 2D polymer-based nanosheets 2D polymer-based nanosheets always possessed substantial intrinsic electrocatalytic active sites associated with the corresponding functional monomers, adjustable hierarchical porous architecture with large specific surface areas, and unique layered nanoscale morphologies, rendering them desirable for potential applications of electrochemical energy storage and conversion, including secondary batteries, supercapacitors, oxygen reduction, and hydrogen evolution. 3.1 Secondary batteries Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs), as the typical rechargeable batteries, have become the new generation electric device for energy storage and conversion, due to the advantages of lithium-ion with heavy-metal free, light weight and high rate performance [131–133]. Recently, 2D organic materials with redox-active sites are emerging as the promising candidates for battery electrode materials. 2D redox COFs with desirable charge transfer and open porous channels could be employed as anode in LIBs [134,135]. Cao and coworkers investigated the adsorption behaviors of Li atoms on the 2D squaraine-linked COFs by using the first principle methods [136]. Theoretical calculation results indicated that 2D COFs could tend to adsorption of Li atoms in a regular symmetry, and Li atom preferred to move across the 1D pores efficiently, due to the very low energy barrier, leading to enhancement of Li storage capacity. Uribe-Romo and co-workers proposed to obtain anisotropic ordering COFs with preferred orientation between hk0 and 00l crystallographic planes through mechanical press [137]. These pellets pretreated from bulk 2D COFs displayed fast Li-ion conductivity up to 0.26 mS cm−1 and high electrochemical stability at room temperature after impregnating with LiClO4, which suggested the potential use of bulk COFs as solid-state electrolytes in batteries. To realize the application in LIBs, Wang et al. exfoliated the pristine redox-active COFs into few-layer nanosheets, which could improve the utilization efficiency of redox sites and kinetics for lithium storage by shortening the Li+ diffusion pathways (Fig. 12 a) [96]. For example, DAAQ-ECOF exhibited a specific capacity of 210 mAh g−1 and a voltage plateau of 2.8 V, as well as fast charge−discharge ability and excellent stability (Fig. 12b–d). Compared with dynamic covalent bond, 2D COP containing porphyrin building block (TThPP) with full sp 2-carbon bond exhibited in-plane high electric conductivity of up to 2.38 × 10− 4 S m−1 [108]. The TThPP films prepared in-situ polymerization on the surface of copper foil could be used as the anode of lithium-ion battery, which exhibited high specific capacities of 82.79 F g−1 at a current density of 50 mA g−1. 2D graphene-based porous carbon, possessing large aspect ratios, well-defined pore structures, high surface areas, and excellent electrical conductivity, demonstrates the appealing electrode material for LIBs [35,37]. Feng and co-workers constructed a kind of 2D carbon sheets via the pyrolysis of sandwich-like porous polyaryltriazine-coupled graphene, showing high conductivity, tunable pore size and high specific surface areas, which could serve as the promising cathode for LIBs [124]. This 2D carbon nanosheet exhibited an outstanding cycle stability of 395 mAh g−1 at 5 A g−1 for more than 5100 cycles and excellent rate capability of 135 mAh g−1 at a high current density of 15 A g−1. Lithium–sulfur (Li–S) batteries have received the increasing attention, due to their high theoretical capacity (1672 mAh g−1), cost effectiveness and environmental friendliness [138–140]. 2D COFs possess their high porosity, low density, insolubility, semi-conductivity and robust stability, which could be used as the host materials in Li–S batteries. Wang and co-workers reported the use of 2D porphyrin-based COFs as the host materials for sulfur storage (Fig. 13 a–e) [141]. Consequently, the as-prepared Li–S battery with 55% sulfur loading in the COF exhibited capacity of 633 mAh g−1 after 200 cycles at 0.5 C charge/discharge rates, along with a capacity decay rate of 0.16% per cycle. Wu and coworkers demonstrated 2D nitrogen-doped porous carbon frameworks as the hosts for sulfur storage, derived from the pyrolysis of sandwich-like polyacrylonitrile functionalized graphene nanosheets (Fig. 13f–j) [126]. As the cathodes for Li–S batteries, these 2D carbon nanosheets exhibited a high capacity up to 962 mAh g−1 after 120 cycles at 2 A g−1, benefiting from their high specific surface area for sulfur loading, fast electronic conduction as well as intimate contact between active materials and electrolyte during cycling. Sodium-ion batteries (NIBs) are considered as promising candidates for economic large-scale energy-storage devices, owing to its low cost, high power capability and long-term stability [142]. Recent studies showed that the porous polymers with continuous interspaces as anodes are much suitable for sodium storage [143]. Loh and co-workers investigated the sodium-storage ability of 2D-CAP nanosheets by the composition of 2D-CAP (75 w%), super P conductive carbon (10 w%) and sodium alginate (15 w%) [109]. This sodium half-cell exhibited a reversible charge capacity of 250 mAh g−1 at the first cycle, and achieved a stable capacity of ∼216 mAh g−1 after ten cycles. Even at a high current density of 10.0 A g−1, a stable capacity of 105 mAh g−1 could be achieved. More importantly, 2D-CAP sodium cell anode achieved an excellent cycle performance over 7700 cycles and retained 70% of its initial capacity of ∼114 mAh g−1 at a high current density of 5.0 A g−1. Feng and co-workers demonstrated the preparation of 2D mesoporous PPy (mPPy) nanosheets, featuring the ultrathin structure, well-defined mesoporous array and high specific surface area, affording their potential applications as the cathode materials for SIBs (Fig. 14 ) [130]. This mPPy electrode exhibited sloping charge/discharge curves, with a reversible discharge capacity of 123 mAh g−1 at 50 mA g−1, which was superior to other PPy-based cathode materials. The excellent cycling stability of the mPPy-based cathode, which maintained an initial capacity of 83 mAh g−1 at a high rate of 300 mA g−1 for 120 cycles, was also found. 3.2 Supercapacitors Electrochemical pseudocapacitors exhibit higher energy density than that of conventional electrical double-layer capacitors (EDLC), which have drawn increasing research interest in recent few years [3]. 2D COFs are promising candidate materials for charge storage devices because of their hierarchical porous structure and high specific surface area [56]. Incorporation of redox active 2,6-diaminoanthraquinone into the framework of COF, Dichtel and co-workers found that the DAAQ-TFP COF displayed reversible redox processes with voltage plateaus at −0.05 V versus Ag/AgCl, indicative of charge transfer to/from the anthraquinones (Fig. 15 a–d) [93]. This pseudocapacitive DAAQ-TFP COF provided a capacitance of 48 ± 10 F g−1 at current densities of 0.1 A g−1 in 1 M H2SO4 electrolyte. The capacitance was stabilized at 40 ± 9 F g−1 after 10 charge/discharge cycles, and showed no further significant decrease after 5000 cycles. Using pyridine as building block [94], The TaPa-Py COF delivered a capacitance of 209 F g−1 at a current density of 0.5 A g−1. Due to the redox transitions of H2Q/Q in nature, TpPa-(OH)2 revealed the predominant pseudocapacitance with a maximum specific capacitance of 416 F g−1 at 0.5 A g−1 current density, which was the highest specific capacitance obtained for COF based materials so far [95]. Moreover, the post-synthesized COF with organic radical also has been exploited as supercapacitors. Jiang and coworkers prepared TEMPO-NiP-COF by immobilizing TEMPO radicals on the walls of COF, which exhibited a pair of reversible peaks clearly [92]. The high capacitance of TEMPO-NiP-COF could reach to 167 F g−1 at 0.1 A g−1 current density. The energy density and cyclic life of COFs in supercapacitors were still limited due to their poor conductivity. To improve capacitive performance, Dichtel and co-workers reported to in situ growth of DAAQ-TFP COF on the Au working electrodes [107], in which a large percentage (80%–99%) of the anthraquinone groups were electrochemically accessible when the thickness of films was smaller than 200 nm, resulting in 400% increase in capacitance as compared to the randomly oriented COF powder. Recently, they enhanced the electrical conductivity of a redox-active 2D DAAQ-TFP COF film by electropolymerization of 3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene (EDOT) within its pores (Fig. 15e–i) [144]. The PEDOT modified DAAQ-TFP film showed significant improvements in volumetric energy and power densities as well as outstanding cycling stability, relative to the unmodified COF films. Semiconducting 2D conjugated polymer framework with fully sp2 -bonded carbon is more desirable for electrochemical application. Yuan et al. reported that 2D poly(2,5-dimethoxyaniline) nanosheets prepared from interfacial polymerization showed the capacitance of ∼330 F g−1 as well as an area specific capacitance of ∼1.9 F m2 at current densities of 0.5 A g−1 in 1 M HCl aqueous solution [116]. Zhang and co-workers reported that the porous carbon nanosheets pyrolyzed from 2D conjugated poly(phenelyenevinylene) framework (2DPPV) with large specific surface areas exhibited an excellent electrochemical performance as supercapacitor electrodes (Fig. 16 a–c) [98]. The specific capacitance of 2DPPV-800, derived from 2DPPV upon pyrolysis at 800 °C was 334 F g−1 at a current density of 0.5 A g−1, and no capacitance loss was observed after 10,000 cycles. Sandwich-like polymer-based nanosheets constructed by the covalent or non-covalent coupling of conjugated porous polymers with 2D graphene is one of the most important supercapacitor electrodes. Feng and co-workers reported the hierarchical graphene oxide/polyaniline (GO/PANI) nanosheets by one-step interfacial electrochemical polymerization, which could be utilized as a flexible all-solid-state supercapacitors with a high specific capacitance of 1095 F g−1 at current densities of 1 A g−1, showing good rate capability and cycling performance [118]. Feng and co-workers demonstrated a versatile protocol for controlled deposition of conductive polymer on the surface of GO (Fig. 16d–f) [75]. As-prepared mPPy@GO exhibit the typical pseudocapacitive behavior of PPy with strong redox peaks in the range of −0.2 to 0.8 V at a low scan rate of 1 mV s−1 with a specific capacitance of 383 F g−1 and good long-term cycling stability. The on-chip all-solid-state planar MSC of this polymer-based nanosheets (mPPy@GO-MSCs) was investigated by using H2SO4/polyvinyl alcohol gel electrolyte. The electrochemical performance of mPPy@GO-MSCs showed a remarkable redox response at different scan rate, and the high areal capacitance of 75.5 mF cm−2 was achieved at scan rate of 10 mV s−1. Porous carbon materials obtained by thermal treatment of sandwich-like polymer-based nanosheets also could be used as supercapacitor electrodes. Zhang and co-workers prepared nitrogen-doping porous carbon materials (TPCs) from graphene coupled Schiff-base porous polymers with nitrogen contents of 5.6%–12.3% and specific surface areas of 323-399 m2 g−1. The electrochemical capacitance of TPCs was calculated to be 424 F g−1 at 0.1 A g−1 under alkaline conditions (6 M KOH) [120]. Considering the high surface area, thinness, good conductivity of 2D polymer-based nanosheets, the redox active inorganic materials could be loaded efficiently to form 2D hybrid nanosheets, making them highly available for application as electrode materials in supercapacitors [145,146]. Feng and co-workers reported to prepared hybrid nanosheets (GO-PANI-Co3O4) by using in-situ hydrothermal synthesis of Co3O4 on the surface of PANI@GO [69]. The highest capacitance of hybrid nanosheets reached to 1063 F g−1 at current densities of 1 A g−1. Remarkably, the specific capacitance of the electrode could be maintained at 1010 F g−1 (>95% capacitance retention) after 2500 cycles. Recently, Zhang and co-workers constructed ferrous phosphide-loading hybrid nanosheets (RG@(Fe2P⊂NPC)) by direct pyrolysis of iron Fe3+ and PO4 3− anchored PANI nanosheets under a hydrogen atmosphere (Fig. 16g–i) [70]. Owing to the high conductivity of porous carbons and the long-distance conductivity in graphene layers, the specific capacitance of RG@(Fe2P⊂NPC) in 6 M KOH was calculated to be as high as 1098 F g−1 at a current density of 1 A g−1, and high performance rate capability with a specific capacitance of 611 F g−1 at 10 A g−1. Furthermore, RG@(Fe2P⊂NPC) showed excellent cycling stability with 77.9% capacitance retention after 1000 cycles. 3.3 Oxygen reduction Fuel cells with many advantages of high energy density, high efficiency, and environmental friendliness are the hot research field in energy storage and conversion [147]. To realize it, development of efficient electrocatalysts for oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) is one of major challenges in the field of fuel cells [148–150]. Recent studies have demonstrated the potential to use heteroatom-doping porous carbon materials as electrocatalysts to replace Pt-based electrodes in fuel cells [151]. 2D carbon materials prepared from 2D polymer-based nanosheets precursors has gained many significant research achievements. Dai and co-workers prepared various N-rich porous polymer nanosheets (COP-X) by using nickel-catalyzed Yamamoto-type Ullmann cross-coupling reaction, which could be carbonized to form 2D carbon nanosheet (C-COP-X) at 950 °C [103]. In their work, the electrocatalytic activities of C-COP-X for ORR in 0.1 M KOH aqueous solution were obtained by using various electrochemical analytic tools. All the four C-COP-X samples showed the well-defined cathodic ORR peaks with O2 within the potential range from 0 to 1.0 V. As expected, C-COP-4 showed an ORR peak at the most positive potential at 0.79 V versus RHE. The transferred electron number (n) per O2 molecule for C-COP-4 calculated by Koutecky–Levich (K–L) equation is 3.90 at 0.55–0.70 V, indicating the primarily four-electron pathway in ORR procedure. Zhang and co-workers reported a kind of sulfur-enriched conjugated polymer nanosheet (2DP-S) consisting of quinoidal polythiophene and poly(p-phenylenevinylene) along horizontal and vertical directions, respectively (Fig. 17 ) [104]. Upon thermal treatment, this 2DP-S could be converted into N S− 1 dual-doped porous carbon nanosheets (2DPCs) with different N S− 1 ratio under ammonia atmosphere. The CV curves for N S-2DPC-60 revealed that the ORR peak- and onset-potentials are 0.65 and 0.77 V versus RHE, respectively, in O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH. According to the RDE voltammetry, the N S-2DPC-800−1 showed the optimal performance with average n of 3.9 obtained from K–L plots, and the J k of 19.2 mA cm−2. Moreover, a superior stability performance was demonstrated as compared with the commercial Pt/C catalyst in avoiding crossover, in which the high persistent relative current of 89.2% was observed after 20,000 s. Owing to the excellent ORR performance, N S-2DPC-60 was further employed to prepare the air cathode for Zn–air batteries. As-prepared battery from N S-2DPC-60 exhibited a peak power density 0.69 mW cm−2 at 2.1 mA cm−2, and excellent cycling stability at 20 mA cm−2 for 12 h with a 10 min cycling period, which could enlighten a light emitting diode LED by using two batteries in series. 2D sandwich-like graphene-based porous polymers become one of important carbon materials precursors. Zhang and co-workers reported the preparation of graphene-based conjugated microporous polymer nanosheets by direct Sonogashira polymerization of thiophene-, thiazole-, and pyridine-based monomers on the surface of bromo‑functionalized RGO, which could be converted into the heteroatom-doping porous carbon nanosheets (GMC-X) upon thermal treatment (Fig. 18 ) [122]. GMC-S showed an ORR onset potential of −0.15 V and a peak potential of −0.28 V versus Ag/AgCl, and the mean number of transferred electrons (n) per O2 molecule involved in the ORR was calculated about 4.0 from K–L equation. For GMC-S catalysts, the diffusion-limiting current densities of J DL = 4.0 mA cm−2 and the kinetic-limiting current of J k = 27.0 mA cm−2 are comparable to commercial Pt/C catalysts. Of note, the half-wave potential (HWP) for the ORR with GMC-S occurred at −0.23 V, which is 52 mV lower than that of microporous carbon without graphene, suggesting a lower operation voltage and lower energy consumption for GMCs with 2D architecture. To gain an insight into the relationship between dimension of porous polymer and ORR performance, Zhang co-workers prepared a series of B/N dual-doped porous carbon on the basis of the different template-based porous polymers from 0D carbon sphere, 1D carbon nanotube to 2D graphene [125]. As the ORR electrodes, these nanocarbon-based zinc–air battery results manifested a strong relationship between morphology and performance (2D > 1D > 0D), and the highest current density of 23.9 mW cm−2 and peak power density of 14.6 mW cm−2 were reached for the 2D porous carbon at 0.61 V. Considering the facile synthetic approach to 2D sandwich-like porous polymers, various heteroatom monomers, like acrylonitrile [123], aniline, m-phenylenediamine, 3-aminobenzeneboronic acid [119], BODIPY [125], 2,5-dibromopyrazine, or 2,4,6-trichloro-1,3,5-triazine [127], could be grafted on the surface of graphene to construct 2D heteroatom-doping porous carbon materials as the efficient electrocatalysts for ORR application. Nitrogen-doped carbon-supported non-precious metal (Fe, Co) materials as the ORR catalysts have attracted tremendous attention in the last few years [152,153]. Incorporation of non-precious-metal into the framework of 2D carbon materials could improve ORR performance. Dai and co-workers prepared the metal-incorporated carbon nanosheets (C-COP-M) upon pyrolysis of 2D COP-M on the basis of metal (Fe, Co, Mn)–porphyrin complexes as monomers [101]. Compared with carbon nanosheets (C-COP), the resultant C-COP-M showed the efficient electrocatalytic activities toward 4e oxygen reduction both in alkaline and acid media with an excellent stability against methanol-crossover/CO-poisoning effects. Besides, metal oxides could be adhered to 2D sandwich-like graphene-based porous polymers for ORR catalysts. Feng and co-workers reported 2D N-doped carbon sheets integrated with the size controlled Co3O4 nanoparticles (GNC-Co), showed the low onset potential in 0.1 M KOH at a rotation rate of 1600 rpm, which is 55 mV higher than that of Pt/C [69]. The calculated value of the electron-transfer number can reach 3.95 at a potential of −0.1 V. The good ORR performance of GNC-Co in 0.5 M H2SO4 was also observed. Recently, bimetallic nanoparticle-based nanomaterials have been used as excellent electrochemical catalysts for ORR. Zhang and co-workers reported to prepared Fe2P and Co2P co-embedded 2D hybrid nanosheets (RG@(Fe2P|Co2P⊂NPC)) through by pyrolysis of both FeCl3 and CoCl2 with graphene-based polyaniline [70]. RG@(Fe2P|Co2P⊂NPC) showed an excellent onset potential of 0.8 V and a half-wave potential of 0.78 V in 0.1 M KOH, which are superior to those of monometallic nanoparticle-based nanomaterials. The half-wave potential difference between RG@(Fe2P|Co2P⊂NPC) and Pt/C was found to be only 49 mV. A four-electron transfer (n = 3.78 at 0.7 V) mechanism with a low yield of H2O2 was calculated, according to the rotating ring-disk electrode experiment. Furthermore, the durability of RG@(Fe2P|Co2P⊂NPC) was tested at a constant voltage of 0.45 V for 20 000 s, the decrease of the relative current (83.5%) was lower than that of Pt/C (81.2%), probably attributable to the well covered metal nanoparticles by carbon layer. 3.4 Hydrogen evolution Electrocatalytic water splitting H2 evolution is another important strategy for exploiting clean fuel cells [154]. Efficient hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) electrocatalysts with low overpotentials are crucial for the successful implementation of water splitting technology [155]. Compared with Pt-based catalysts, the earth-abundant non-precious metal-based electrocatalysts with low costs are highly desirable [156]. Feng and co-workers reported the synthesis of multi-layer 2D polymer nanosheets (Co-2DP) by polycondensation of 5,10,15,20-tetrakis(4-aminophenyl)-21H,23H-porphyrin-Co(II) with 2,5-dihydroxyterephthalaldehyde at water–chloroform interface [110]. The resulting Co-2DP deposited onto a Ti electrode as electrocatalyst for HER in 1.0 M aqueous KOH solution, exhibiting an excellent electrocatalytic activity for HER, which required an overpotential of about 367 mV to reach current density of 1.0 mA cm−2. The onset potential of 308 mV and the Tafel slope of 126 mV decade−1 were calculated from the polarization curve. Porous carbon nanosheets with high conductivity and hierarchical microporous/mesoporous structure are an ideal substrate to load transition metals nanoparticles for HER. Zhang and co-workers synthesized a Mo2C-embedded N-doped porous carbon nanosheet (Mo2C@2D-NPC) by the thermal treatment of Mo4O13 2−-loading GO@PANI nanosheets (Fig. 19 ) [157]. This hybrid nanosheet exhibited an extremely low onset potential of ∼0 mV, a current density of 10 mA cm−2 at an overpotential of ∼45 mV as well as Tafel slope of 46 mV decade−1, which is comparable to the noble Pt catalyst. This outstanding HER performance was attributed to the synergistic effect of nitrogen doping, high conductivity, and abundant active sites of the heterostructures of Mo2C@2D-NPC. 4 Summary and outlook In this feature article, we have witnessed the significant progress in the preparation of 2D polymer-based nanosheets, and their electrochemical applications in energy storage and conversion. The 2D geometric frameworks of polymer-based nanosheets could be constructed conveniently by versatile synthetic approaches, including random polymerization, interfacial polymerization, and template-directed polymerization, and thus the chemical structures and morphologies of their layered skeletons can be finely tailored to form crystalline or amorphous state. In comparison with traditional 2D soft nanomaterials (e.g. graphene, h-BN, g-C3N4), the 2D polymer-based nanosheets featuring much complex topological structures exhibit many extra advantages, including substantially tunable electronic structures, controllable hierarchical porous structure, and feasible combination of various active components into the polymeric networks, as well as the relatively low-cost preparation in large scale. Consequently, these 2D polymer-based nanosheets are therefore rendered with very rich physical properties, such as good charge transfer, large mass transport and effectively exposed active sites, which is favorable for high-performance electrochemical energy storage and conversion, including second batteries, supercapacitors, oxygen reduction and hydrogen evolution. Although a lot of improvements in 2D polymer-based nanosheets have already been achieved greatly, this field is still in an early stage, and there is still a long way with huge challenges toward either academic investigation or commercial application. Currently, in order to resolve some urgent issues, the following improvements seems to be carefully consideration: (1) Rational design and synthesis of new building blocks with rich redox activities and good semiconducting properties for constructing novel 2D polymer-based nanosheets with excellent reversible redox process and tunable electrochemical windows within a wide range; (2) Searching for efficient synthetic strategies for achieving single- or few-layered 2D flakes with enlarged sizes up to macroscale; (3) Exploring new dynamic covalent polymerization for improving the stabilities and semiconducting behaviors of 2D polymeric networks associated with high crystallinity and long-range order; (4) Combining with traditional thin-film technologies, including chemical vapor deposition (CVD), physical vapor deposition (PVD), the development of precise fabrication approaches to 2D polymer-based devices with high-performance electrochemical properties is highly desirable for highly efficient energy storage and conversion. On the assumption that these difficulties are overcome, 2D polymer-based nanosheets will hold great promises for energy application. Meanwhile, the established new synthetic methods would create substantial 2D polymer-based nanosheets with finely tailored structure, beneficially shed a light on the correlation of the unique physical properties with 2D structure/morphologies for such kinds of materials. He then joined the group of Professor Fan Zhang at Shanghai Jiao Tong University for Doctoral Training and began doctoral studies in September 2014 where his research interests focus on conjugated semiconducting polymers for energy conversion and storage. Chenbao Lu received his B.S. degree in Chemical Engineering and Technology from Nanjing University of Technology in June 2014 and received Master degree from Shanghai Jiao Tong University in March 2017. Then he joined in the group of Professor Fan Zhang at Shanghai Jiao Tong University and began doctoral studies in April 2017. He focuses on fabricated 2D materials for energy storage and conversion. Wenbei Zhang received his Master degree in School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering from Henan Normal University in June 2012. He then joined the group of Professor Fan Zhang at Shanghai Jiao Tong University and began doctoral studies in September 2013 where his research interests focus on conjugated porous organic polymers for energy conversion and storage. Feng Qiu received his BSc and MSc degrees from Taiyuan University of Technology, and obtained his Ph.D. degree from Shanghai Jiao Tong University. Then, he did his postdoctoral research at Shanghai Jiao Tong University under the supervision of Prof. Xinliang Feng and Prof. Fan Zhang. He joined Shanghai Institute of Technology as a Lecturer in 2015. His current research interests focus on the controlled preparation of functional polymers and their applications in electrochemical energy storage and conversion. Fan Zhang received his BEng degree in electrochemistry from Shanghai Jiao Tong University in 1991, and his Ph.D. in organic chemistry from Jilin University in 2000. After more than 8 years of research experience in Germany and the United States, he was promoted to a Research Professor in School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering of Shanghai Jiao Tong University, China. His research interest is organic π-conjugated functional materials for energy conversion and storage.

coredata.dc:description: Over the past decades, two-dimensional (2D) nanomaterials possessing planar layered architecture and unique electronic structures have been being quickly developed, due to their wide potential application in the fields of chemistry, physics, and materials science. As a new family of 2D nanomaterials, 2D polymer-based nanosheets, featuring excellent characters, such as tunable framework structures, light weight, flexibility, high specific surface, and good semiconducting properties, have been emerging as one kind of promising functional materials for optoelectronics, gas separation, catalysis and sensing, etc. In this review, the recent progress in synthetic approach and characterization of 2D polymer-based nanosheets were summarized, and their current advances in electrochemical energy storage and conversion including second batteries, supercapacitors, oxygen reduction and hydrogen evolution were discussed systematically.
